entry.title: Why are dimension attributes not available in Calculated Dimensions in a SAC Story?
entry.content:
Problem Statement

We are using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with a live connection to an Analytic Model (AM) created on top of a Fact Table  in SAP Datasphere.

We observed that:

  • When trying to create Calculated Dimensions within the SAC , only keys and columns from the Fact Table are available.
  • Attributes from associated Dimension Tables are not visible for use in formula expressions inside Calculated Dimensions.
  • However, those same attributes can be displayed in SAC stories without issue.

In below example only keys and dimension attributes from FACT are available and not all the attributes from the Dimension tables joined with FACT -

 

Question:

Why are dimension attributes (from Dimension Tables joined with FACT) not available in Calculated Dimensions, even though they appear in the SAC story view?

In my opinion, this behavior is due to the live connection architecture and how SAC interprets model metadata from Datasphere:

  1. SAC only allows calculated logic (e.g., Calculated Dimensions) to reference fields that are part of the Analytic Model schema.

  2. When the AM is built directly on a Fact Table/View, it only includes the foreign keys, not the descriptive attributes of related dimensions.

  3. In a live connection, SAC pushes all calculation logic to Datasphere, so fields must be explicitly present in the underlying dataset or view for them to be available in formulas.

To make dimension attributes available in Calculated Dimensions within SAC, we have used Graphical Views with Explicit Joins

  • In Datasphere, created a Graphical View where we joined the dimension tables to the Fact Table using foreign keys.

  • This exposed both keys and attributes in the resulting Analytic Model, making them available in SAC for both display and calculations.
  • With this approach we can see all the attributes also from Dimension Tables/Views in a Calculated Dimension Formula.

 

 

Is this the correct approach? or is there alternative approach?

Can we avoid using Graphical Views (with explicit joins) and still access all necessary attributes for calculated logic?

entry.title: Re: S4HPC - Clear Outgoing Payments: Journal Entry Paymen...
entry.content:
Hi Chuma.

Solution was found. 

CDS are useful here:

  • i_operationalacctgdocitem
  • I_SupplierCompany

Required event handler: if_fins_je_event_handler

API for updating Payment Reason: i_journalentrytp

Code: 

 DATA lt_aparitem         LIKE <je>-%param-_aparitems.
    DATA ls_aparitem         LIKE LINE OF lt_aparitem.
    DATA ls_aparitem_control LIKE ls_aparitem-%control.
    ls_aparitem_control-glaccountlineitem     = if_abap_behv=>mk-on.
    ls_aparitem_control-paymentblockingreason = if_abap_behv=>mk-on.

    " Data
    <je>-accountingdocument = iv_accounting_document.
    <je>-fiscalyear         = iv_fiscal_year.
    <je>-companycode        = iv_company_code.
    <je>-%param             = VALUE #( _aparitems = VALUE #( ( glaccountlineitem     = '001'
                                                               paymentblockingreason = lv_payment_block
                                                               %control              = ls_aparitem_control ) ) ).

    MODIFY ENTITIES OF i_journalentrytp
     ENTITY journalentry
     EXECUTE change FROM lt_je
     FAILED DATA(ls_failed_deep)
     REPORTED DATA(ls_reported_deep)
     MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped_deep).

Sequence of steps: 

  1. Catch event
  2. Update JE in parallel process (as RAP does not allow do it directly)
  3. In our case 'parallel process' was a scheduling of Application Job.

Regards

Vitali

entry.title: Connect & Go: Integration Updates for 2025/1
entry.content:
A seamlessly connected business is more crucial than ever as organizations pursue agility and innovation. Just like the capabilities of SAP Integration Suite that enable you to connect everything in your business, the Connect & Go series brings you a recap of the highlights for the product and how you can get started and integrate with confidence across SAP and non-SAP landscapes.

In the first half of 2025, SAP Integration Suite has delivered new features and enhancements, reaffirming its role as the AI-assisted IPaaS for seamless connectivity, automation, and data-driven decision making. As you dive into this post, you will explore AI updates, expanded capabilities for migration to Integration Suite, latest additions to third-party connectivity and API-centric and event-driven integration. Enjoy!

 

üíéAI Updates

SAP Integration Suite introduced a new user experience that empowers developers to use AI capabilities more effectively in their development, configuration, migration, testing, and workload monitoring tasks. This revamped interface aimed to enhance overall productivity and operational excellence, with a consolidated landing page offering a unified view and central activation control for all AI features.

AI-assisted API trends and predictions

Now organizations can leverage AI and machine learning to analyze historical API call volumes and forecast trends and provide insights into traffic patterns.

Deviations from the normal usage or performance in API traffic often indicate security threats, system malfunctions, or other issues that might result in financial loss. This feature addresses this challenge through ML-based anomaly detection, which identifies unusual or abnormal behaviors by continuously monitoring the API traffic. Upon detection of anomalies in API Call Volume, API Error count, and API Response time, the system provides notifications and insights to support investigating the cause and analyzing the impact, as well as recommendations on probable remedial actions. Customers can customize options to select specific API proxies, choose the prediction duration, and set the frequency according to their preferences. With this feature they can proactively adjust their strategies, improving their resilience and competitive edge to maintain the security, reliability, and performance of their APIs. Read more: Leveraging API Traffic Predictions in SAP Integration Suite.

 

üì¶SAP Business Accelerator Hub News

That the SAP Business Accelerator Hub is the one-stop-shop for pre-built business accelerators you already know. But now, it includes Joule-based discovery and reuse of artifacts to help customers and partners find the right content faster and more intuitively. For an even smoother experience, the hub provides quick access to AI-specific APIs, events, and integrations in a dedicated space. 

And last but not least, the hub now includes a wide range of content for Data Products. Users can explore these products within SAP Business Data Cloud that are built to help businesses manage, analyze, and maximize the value of their data. Offerings include curated datasets, data integration tools, and analytics applications, all designed to support informed, data-driven decision-making.

 

üí° Migration and Modernization

Support of Exactly-Once-In-Order scenario (EOIO)

EOIO is essential in business scenarios where the receiving system requires messages to be received exactly once in the correct order, such as banking operations like deposits and withdrawals, where message order is critical. This functionality supports EOIO via exclusive queues in Cloud Integration and exclusive or partitioned queues using Advance Event Mesh. It ensures no duplicate messages or message loss, as well as the preservation of message sequence during processing.

To learn more about EOIO and how to configure Java Message Service (JMS) adapter, check out New integration flow design guidelines covering Exactly Once In Order pattern, the documentation, and the sample integration flows on SAP Business Accelerator Hub. For AEM, see Exactly once in order (EOIO) for Group messages using Advanced Event Mesh.

Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for IDOCs

New modernization recommendations now include evaluations of different IDOC types in integration scenarios. The respective SOAP/ODATA APIs and Business Events are recommended according to the content on SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Customers can leverage these recommendations during migration to obtain risk and cost reduction when adopting a clean core approach. The additional information is reported in the full evaluation result spreadsheet, learn how to extract the data with a Data Extraction Request or follow the tutorial.

 

üîóThird-party Connectivity

In this first half of 2025 we‚Äôve expanded our ecosystem to help customers integrate across platforms effortlessly. A new set of integration adapters include: IBM MQ (REST, JMS), SAP LeanIX, Google Cloud Storage, Google Pub/Sub, Google BigQuery, Salesforce Pub/Sub, DocuSign, MS 365 Teams, MS 365 OneDrive, Shopify, and more. Additionally, the Remote Function Call (RFC) sender and receiver adapter was made available in Edge Integration Cell to allow direct, on-premise communication with SAP and third-party systems without relying on the SAP Cloud Connector, allowing these systems to initiate RFC calls.

Data Space Integration

The Data Space Integration feature of SAP Integration Suite was made available in Q2 enabling participants within a data space, such as Catena-X, to exchange data with one another in a secure, reliable, and sovereign way. It provides straightforward integration between SAP and non-SAP applications and offers a unified, user-friendly approach to configuring and monitoring data exchanges within the data space, all using the SAP Integration Suite - learn more.

 

üöÄAPI-centric and event-driven integration

Single-source API and events catalog for developers

The API business hub enterprise is now the Developer Hub: a centralized catalog designed for application developers to easily discover, search, and utilize APIs and business events published by their organizations. Customers can benefit from building an extensive company-wide repository of APIs and events, including thorough documentation and code examples, as well as new features like self-registration and analytics. All to empower developers to efficiently integrate various systems and applications. Start exploring: check out how you can Discover S/4HANA Cloud Events in SAP Developer Hub and Enable SAP Developer Hub as central Event Catalog; and read the documentation for APIs and Events. 

 

SAP SuccessFactors events on SAP Business Accelerator Hub‚Äã

Explore the new events for SAP SuccessFactors published on SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Stay tuned for more events to come!

Event add-on for SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA

This add-on for SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC allows the creation of custom events based on different trigger types. These events can be both notification and data events and allow for loosely coupled, highly scalable, real-time event-driven business architectures powered by SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Users can easily configure the add-on and create their custom extensible events with or without code, as well as leverage templates for selected events.

Find all relevant details for this exciting update in the blog: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAP‚Äôs new Event-Add for ERP.

 

The next edition of Connect & Go is scheduled for September/October 2025. Until then:

- Stay informed | Read the Related Updates:

  • Generative AI-based script optimization ‚Äì Q1 25
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub domains take centerstage ‚Äì Q1 25
  • New Partner Content on SAP Business Accelerator Hub - Q2 25
  • Integration Advisor ‚Äì multi-payload support for MIG creation - Q3 25
  • Update Version of an Integration Flow Component - Q3 25
  • Partner Directory Accelerator Tool for Pipeline Concept  ‚Äì Q3 25

- Stay in Touch:

  • Join the monthly update webinars 
  • Interact in the Integration group
  • Subscribe to the Newsletter

entry.title: Re: Extended situation handling issues on SAP S/4HANA 202...
entry.content:
The Job (SIT2_RT_BATCH) is required to run to get the batch runs working, but don't expect that once you run that more frequently you can run your Situation Type every 30 min when you schedule this job to run more frequently - this is done independently from the batch schedule within our engine.
The documentation for the job is here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/8308e6d301d54584a33cd04a9861bc52/4a6e11863b60401083125db64041d11f.html?locale=en-US

The reason why it's not working might be (but I don't know as I can't see) that you only have event triggers - these are run when there is an incoming event to which they react. 
In case of batch you need to use the 2nd (Batch) Tirgger type. Maybe you missed that in your configuation?

entry.title: Re: need information - modify database SAP
entry.content:
1. Doubt you would have a problem with this, as long as you use some naming convention that will surely not clash with SAP naming of procedures, and you don't perform forbidden actions within this procedure.

2. Realisticall, this shouldn't cause any issues to the database but I wouldn't risk doing it in production database. I would do one of the following:

  • use UDT instead of creating table via SQL
  • create a new separate database and create this table in this separate database (you can perform operations from production database in this separate database with adequate privileges)

entry.title: Re: Freely- defined currency typeÊòØÂê¶ÂèØÊåâ10„ÄÅ30Ë¥ßÂ∏ÅÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÈÄªËæëÂèÇ‰∏éÁâ©ÊñôËØÑ‰º∞ÔºüÊòØ...
entry.content:
Hi @Joey3 ,

I had to use the machine translation below, please keep that in mind when interpreting my answer.

We are able to manage and store inventory prices for all ledgers and currency types which are configured in the general ledger. This also includes any customer specific currency types like Z1 in your example. The costing process itself (CK11N/CK40N) does create a cost estimate in currency 10 and 30 only. This is also the reason why you do not see Z1 or any other freely defined currency in those apps. When you go ahead and mark the cost estimate for release, a currency translation takes place which calculated the amount for Z1. This price is then used after release to valuation your inventories and any goods movements in this currency.

At the moment there is no possibility to treat Z1 like 10 or 30 in the costing process, meaning a direct calculation in this currency on the individual quantity structure (bill of material + routing) items is not possible. In MR21/MR22 you can manually maintain a price or post a debit/credit for this material for currency Z1. CKM3 is able to show all currencies.

For this entire process it does not matter if Z1 is selected as the functional currency or if - for example - 10 remains the functional currency for the company code. Z1 will always be translated when marking a cost estimate. The functional currency flag plays a role in different processes like in foreign currency valuation.

Z1 will participate in the actual costing process and will be treated individually, e.g. when entering an amount for Z1 in MR22, this debit/credit will be considered in the actual costing process for Z1.

I hope this helped. In case you have any more questions, feel free to ask them. If this answered your question, please mark this as the accepted solution. Thank you.

Best regards
Marvin

entry.title: A Look Back At CodeConnect 2025
entry.content:
A Look Back At CodeConnect 2025

It's been almost 2 weeks now since I participated in the 2025 CodeConnect event, which was actually my first in-person CodeConnect ever.
I would've participated in person sooner, but getting tickets is akin to trying to get the most popular item on Black Friday, it requires speed, precision and luck!

But enough rambling about the tickets! Let's take a look back at my journey to CodeConnect 2025.

UI5Con 2025

I'm going to skip the very first day of CodeConnect, mainly due to it being spent in a car for 16 hours, as me and my colleagues made the journey from the northern part of Jutland to St. Leon Rot.
So for us, the conference didn't start until day 2 with UI5Con, and that was some start.

Upon arrival at the building, it was straight into networking and trying to decide what sessions were most interesting to participate in.
We ended up doing a divide and conquer strategy in our group to get the most out of the day, with of course a focus on getting to the hands-on sessions.

My day quickly became side-tracked as I caught up with both old and new faces in my effort to connect with all the other developers present at the event.
Which, to be honest, for a mostly backend/cloud guy like me wasn't all bad. While I do enjoy a tango with the frontend from time to time, my heart belongs to what goes on behind the scenes.

But I did catch a lot of good talks still; so here are my take-aways from the first real day at CodeConnect:

  • Ownership of styling is slowly being handed back to the developer, meaning we can now make proper custom components for UI5 that style correctly with the themes such as Horizon.
  • Still no clear release date for UI5 v2, but we do have a legacy free 1.136 out there now that we can utilize and prepare with
  • Promise for UI5 developers that keep in line with the UI5 Linter, that their code will be lift and shift (i.e. go use the linter asap!)
  • The UI5 repository has completed its moving phase and is now living in its own repository
  • Accessibility, much like everywhere else in the developer space at the moment, is the talk of the town, and SAP is doing a lot of improvements on this front
  • 2 test runners were presented as the replacements for the deprecated Karma runner. I know that I am leaning the most towards the WDI5 route due to it working as a more complete suite.
  • Webcomponents are the main focus going forward, and even though there is no timestamp on it, it seems like it will replace many of our current components going forward

That was pretty much my experience and take-aways for the first day there, and with it we wrapped up the UI5Con with some great food before heading back to the hotel.
The next for me, I knew would be something special.

reCAP 2025

Second day for me at CodeConnect started out with a great opening key note by Daniel Hutzel. Although he ran out of time by the end, I wish we could've listened to him for just a little while longer.

The key take-away of this keynote however, was extremely clear. Over the last year, the focus by the CAP team has really been on minimizing the footprint of the CAP/CDS install while optimizing and improving the feature set of the framework.
And from what we were presented, that definitely looked like it came out as a success. As a developer that uses CAP on a daily basis, both for plugin development and end-user projects, I can definitely say that I have enjoyed the improvements so far.

So a kudos to the CAP team is definitely in order on this! (Now we just need it to be open source!)

Unfortunately, I did not have as much time to participate in the many sessions of this day, as much like the day before, the event became more of a networking experience.
The sessions I did catch however, were absolutely great and definitely something that you should catch up on if you have the chance;

  • Both sessions by Mike Zaschka (just always a good listen and everybody loves open source!)
  • CAP Tools session by Christian Georgi (because you cannot be a good developer without knowing your tools)
  • Server-side Pre-rendering by Volker Buzek and Wouter Lemaire (a great session with insights into another great open source initiative)
  • CAP Best vs Bad Practices by Daniel Hutzel
  • Gain a superpower by learning how to harness the CDS REPL by DJ Adams (seriously, learn REPL)

While these were the only sessions I managed to catch, I did however experience something extremely important during the reCAP event, and that was the community.

I got to connect with so many great people and talk about the passion of this side of the industry, and the love we all share for opens source technologies.

I even got the chance to appear on the SAP Developer News to share my own open source contribution (MCP Plugin for CAP).

And that is something I wouldn't trade for anything.

You Should Attend

I hope it is clear from my post here that going to CodeConnect is an experience, no matter how you plan it. It is an event filled with great people and some great discussions around the subjects we all work with on a daily basis.

Never in a million years would I have imagined that going to CodeConnect would have resulted in me getting to participate in the SAP Developer News, nor that I would get to have great open discussions with other open source contributors.
It is definitely worth it, so if you get the chance I highly recommend that you participate!

Hopefully I will get the chance to contribute to the speakers list next year!

entry.title: Re: Situation Handling: Advanced Configuration of Situation Types (5-5)
entry.content:
Hi J√ºrgen,

while you would be able to subscribe to Business Situation events (Event References | Business Situation Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub), and specifically is Business Situation Completed events (v1 for Standard Framework, v2 for Extended Framework), I suspect the practical use is limited as they have been created mainly for further processing of situations on BTP and contain no information about the business object on which the situation exists/existed.

We currently also don't provide any BAdIs or similar exits that would allow custom post-processing after a situation has been closed. 

So unfortunately, the only thing I can currently suggest is that you create a feature request for this in the Customer Influence portal (Improvement Request Lists - Customer Influence, please use the tag "Situation Handling"), and if it gets ranked high enough in our backlog, we will look into this and check if we can either enhance the existing events or find another suitable way to address this requirement.

Best regards,
Sebastian

Building the Composable Storefront From Libraries

entry.title: Joule in SAP Ariba Applications
entry.content:
Joule is the SAP AI copilot - a virtual assistant that uses a conversational interface to help users of SAP business applications complete tasks more efficiently.

The conversational interface is brought to life with the help of these 4 interaction patterns:

  • With informational interactions we are providing our users knowledge-based results. All SAP applications in which Joule is available make their knowledge-base available via Joule, e.g. SAP Help Documentation. This is managed by SAP and offered to every Joule user out of the box.
    We‚Äòre also bringing in Document Grounding with which we enable our customers to upload their customer-owned content, e.g. HR-policies, travel-policies, FAQs, and others, so that their users can ask questions based on these documents.

 

  • Navigational Pattern - Easily navigate SAP applications by simply asking via natural language. Joule offers you a navigational link which opens the respective application and UI in a new browser tab. In the destination, a user can open Joule again and continue where they have left with the same conversation history.

 

  • Transactional interactions provide our users with a direct entry point to the backend system. Triggering and influencing business processes with the power of natural language and AI. E.g. purchase orders which need to be reviewed and approved, job positions which are created or any other CRUD-interaction (create, read, update, delete) within SAP cloud applications.

 

  • And a 4th, Analytical pattern to enable analytical interactions based on JustAsk and SAP Analytics Cloud, enabling customers to leverage Joule for analytical queries. This is currently not implemented in Ariba.

With the Q3 2025 release, Joule is being made available in the SAP Ariba applications of Guided Buying, Guided Sourcing and Supplier Management.

Please note that AI copilot Joule in the aforementioned products will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it will be made generally available to customers.

Below is the complete list of Transactional and Navigational Joule skills which are available per application area.

1. Guided Buying

Available Transactional Joule Skills

  • Get Status of Purchase Requisition ‚Äì Displays the status of a specific PR
  • Show recent purchase requisitions ‚Äì Displays a list of the last 10 PRs
  • Show Approvers of PR
  • Show Shipping Details
  • Show PR Details ‚Äì Displays line item information of a specified PR

Available Navigational Joule Skills

  • View Requisition

2. Guided Sourcing

Available Transactional Joule Skills

  • List Sourcing Events - Displays the list of sourcing events created within a specified number of past days.
  • Return RFx status of a sourcing event ‚Äì Displays the status of a specific event ID
  • Return approval status of a sourcing event ‚Äì Displays the status of an approval task for the specified event
  • Send reminder email to Suppliers
  • Retrieve Supplier Invitation Details
  • Retrieve Event Timing or Event Rules
  • Display pending approvals
  • Approval Processing
  • Sourcing Approval Status Check
  • Retrieve Supplier Bids
  • Retrieve Supplier Bid Details

Available Navigational Joule Skills

  • Go to My Tasks
  • Go to For You page
  • Go to Sourcing Event
  • Go to Request Creation page

3. Supplier Management

Available Transactional Joule Skills

  • Show Primary Contact Information of Supplier ‚Äì Displays contact details of Supplier
  • List Suppliers ‚ÄòIn Registration‚Äô status - Displays a list of suppliers that have started the registration process but haven't submitted questionnaires for a specific number of days.
  • List Suppliers ‚ÄòInvited‚Äô status ‚Äì Displays a list of the Suppliers that have been invited to register but haven‚Äôt responded to the invitation for a specific number of days

Available Navigational Joule Skills

  • Navigate to get Suppliers in Registration status
  • Navigate to get Suppliers in Invited status

Additionally, the Informational pattern is also available for the 3 applications which means Joule can assist users with your product-related questions by finding answers in the product documentation published on the SAP Help Portal. Along with an excerpt, it provides direct links to the relevant source documents, allowing you to explore the details further.

 

COSTING 

All the above mentioned Joule skills are part of Joule base, which means you will not be charged any AI units for these. 

You should have enabled either of the below Joule SKUs from SAP store

  • Joule Base SKU: 8019544
  • Joule Premium SKU (includes AI Units): 8019164

 

MULTI-LANGUAGE SUPPORT 

Joule will be able to understand and respond to queries in the following languages - English, German, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Vietnamese, Greek, Polish.

 

PREREQUISITES

Joule leverages the SAP Business Technology Platform to simplify complex integration landscapes. So the very first prerequisite is a BTP account.

1. SAP Ariba applications license : You have a license for one or more of the aforementioned SAP Ariba applications in one of the supported data centers supported by Joule, as Joule is an embedded application that is integrated with SAP products. The currently supported data centers are listed here.

2. SAP BTP : Joule leverages the SAP Business Technology Platform to simplify complex integration landscapes, which makes it the next prerequisite. You should have an enterprise global account on SAP BTP. If you already have a global account in SAP BTP, Joule entitlements can be added in the same global account.

To activate or setup Joule, you need to have the following BTP services.

3. SAP Cloud Identity Services : SAP Cloud Identity Services are a group of services of SAP BTP which enable you to handle provision and integrate identity and access management between systems, providing you a seamless SSO experience across systems with the security. SAP Cloud Identity Services are bundled with an SAP cloud solution, which means you are entitled to one productive and one test tenant preconfigured with the SAP cloud solution (Refer this link). You should have integrated the SAP Ariba application with Identity Authentication as Joule leverages the IAS setup of the SAP product for user login.

4. SAP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition : To support navigation to different applications from Joule and handle role based access scenarios, you need to configure the navigation service of SAP Build Work Zone. Joule uses the navigation service component of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition to resolve intent based navigation targets and configure additional content providers.

5. You have created a subaccount in your global account using the SAP BTP cockpit for provisioning Joule. A single Joule subscription can be integrated into multiple SAP products like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, or SAP Build Work Zone. However, one subscription of the Joule application can only be integrated with one tenant of an SAP product. This means you cannot include multiple systems of the same product in one Joule formation. You must ensure that there is one IAS tenant per single independent entity and operate every single independent entity from its own dedicated SAP BTP sub-account.

 

LIMITATIONS AS OF Q3 2025 RELEASE

 Buyer Parent-Child MERP (Multi-ERP) realm setup issue in Guided Buying : Joule does not currently support multi-tenant consolidation. To overcome this limitation Customers must run Joule Booster in every child realm. This also means there will be no data consolidation across the realms

entry.title: SAP Ariba Category Management 2508 Release Highlights
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community and welcome to the 2508 key innovations blog for SAP Ariba Category Management 

As organizations continue to adapt to evolving market dynamics, the need for efficient and intelligent category management tools becomes more critical than ever. At SAP, we‚Äôre committed to continuously enhancing SAP Ariba Category Management‚Äîempowering you to streamline processes, drive collaboration, and make data-driven decisions.

Our Q3 2025 release introduces a range of powerful new features designed with your needs in mind. Here‚Äôs a quick look at the business value these updates bring to your sourcing and procurement teams.

 

1. Ability to Set an Initiative as Obsolete in SAP Ariba Category Management (ARBCATA-463)

Keeping your workspace organized is essential for focus and efficiency. With this feature you can now manually mark outdated initiatives as obsolete, easily closing those that are no longer relevant. This means your team will see only initiatives that matter, reducing clutter and helping everyone prioritize more effectively.

Additionally, the Initiatives Overview page now allows you to filter by multiple phases‚Äîincluding the Obsolete phase‚Äîso you can quickly get the view you need and keep data clean and actionable.

 

2. Reassign Strategy and Plan Document ownership (ARBCATA-471)

Organizational change is a normal part of business, but it shouldn‚Äôt interrupt progress. Whether someone moves to a new role, takes leave, or exits the company, you can now ensure ongoing access, editing rights, and continuity‚Äîwithout the need for workarounds or data bottlenecks.

Previously, only the lead category manager could access and edit a strategy and plan document after the original owner was no longer active. With this feature, category managers can reassign ownership of a category strategy and plan document to another category manager from the same team.

 

 

3. Standardized and Detailed Category Risk Assessment (ARBCATA-489)

Risk management is fundamental to strong category strategies. With this feature , the risk assessment tool has been enhanced so administrators can define standardized risk types for evaluation across all purchasing categories.

The new Risk Types page on the Strategy and Plan tab

Category managers can now identify, score, and qualify each risk in detail, with information like cause, impact, and mitigation strategies.

The New Risk page that appears when you click Create on the Risk Assessment page now includes 3 sections: Assessment, Details, and Mitigation

These scores contribute to an overall risk score at the strategy and plan level, which reflects the combined risk across category, timeframe, business unit, and region. This gives category managers a structured, repeatable approach to assessing category supporting informed decision-making at every level.

The Risk Assessment page now displays a Risk Assessment Matrix and Risks table

 

4. Ability to Add and Manage Attachments on Initiatives (CATMAN-442)

Collaborating on initiatives just became easier. With this feature, category managers can now add relevant documents, files, or links directly to any initiative - improving transparency and ensuring the team has the context it needs.

Importantly, adding attachments doesn‚Äôt reset document status or require reapproval. Your plans stay up to date and in their current workflow, even as you enhance them with supporting information.

 

5. Add multiple Tool Documents for Deeper, Flexible Analysis (CATMAN-454)

Category management often requires nuanced analysis across various regions or business units. With this feature, you can add multiple tool documents of the same analysis tool - such as multiple Cost Structure or Market Dynamics documents - to a single strategy and plan. This makes it easy to compare findings across categories, regions, or business units - helping you make more informed, data-driven decisions.

 

6. Ability to Select Tool Documents for AI-generated Category Strategy Recommendations (CATMAN-16)

Now that it‚Äôs possible (with the above feature) to create multiple Cost Structure and Market Dynamics documents, this new AI-driven strategy recommendations allows you to choose which Cost Structure and Market Dynamics documents to include, ensuring the insights you receive are tailored to your specific business needs. This accelerates the development of effective strategies, minimizing revisions and aligning recommendations with your goals.

You can now choose specific Cost Structure and Market Dynamics documents when generating recommendations for category strategy details, in cases where multiple tool documents are linked to a strategy and plan document

 

7. Ability to create Custom Strategy and Plan Tools with Document Templates (CATMAN-469)

Every business is unique, and now your tools can be, too. Administrators can create custom strategy and plan tools - complete with document templates - directly in the Manage Configurations app. This ensures your teams have a standardized starting point and can easily comply with internal best practices, while still allowing flexibility to upload and refine working documents.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Source to Contract 2508 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community and welcome to our 2508 key innovations blog. We're thrilled to unveil the latest features in our Q1 2025 release for SAP Ariba's source-to-contract solutions. 

Here‚Äôs a closer look at what‚Äôs new this quarter:

 

SAP Ariba Contract Management

SAP Ariba Contracts Integration with WalkMe (SCONTR-1444)

WalkMe integrated is now available in SAP Ariba Contracts.WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform provides step-by-step guidance directly within the app. It's ideal for helping users complete common tasks like examples in the screenshot below.

The idea behind is simple, if we have to spend less time try to figuring out how to do the task, we'll get more time getting things done, and that's what we aim to achieve this this integration

 

Managing Baseline and Supplier Contracts for Pre-Award Negotiation in Icertis Contract Intelligence for SAP Ariba Solutions (SCONTR-1499)

If your organization uses Icertis Contract Intelligence (ICI) alongside SAP Ariba, there's good news. You can now manage both baseline and supplier contracts directly in Icertis during pre-award negotiations.

We've also improved the APIs so that developers can easily copy data from one contract workspace to another.

 

SAP Ariba Guided Sourcing

AI Copilot Joule in Guided Sourcing (SOURCE-2725)

We‚Äôre excited to introduce Joule, SAP‚Äôs generative AI copilot, in Guided Sourcing, currently in Early Access. AI Copilot Joule in Guided Sourcing will be generally available to customers on September 19th, 2025.

With Joule, we hope that our users will be able to complete tasks, find information, and navigate the platform easier and quicker.

 

Ability to Create Partitioned Events in Guided Sourcing (SOURCE-2342)

For teams handling big or complex sourcing projects, we‚Äôve added partitioned events.

This lets individual sourcing team members manage their own groups of suppliers. They can invite participants, track their bids, and update terms independently without needing full project ownership rights.

 

Display Remaining Time for Line Items in Bid Console for Guided Sourcing Auctions and Competitive RFPs (SOURCE-2544)

Timing matters! The bid console now clearly shows how much time is left per line item during auctions and RFPs.

.With this release, buyers can now see the remaining time for each line item or lot directly. 

 

The changes are applicable for competitive RFP, Auction, Reverse auction bid console screens. For Japanese, dutch auctions the new column Time remaining will not show and the watch screen timer values will not change.

 

Support for Event Search Filters on the Supplier Home Page in Sourcing Events (SOURCE-2585)

Suppliers can now use their home page to set personalized search filters for sourcing events.

They can filter events by region, commodity, or dates, and even save these filters for future logins. They can filter events by region, commodity, or dates, and even save these filters for future logins. This small improvement makes life easier for suppliers, especially those are handling multiple event across regions or in different categories.

---

 

This quarter‚Äôs release are practical changes based on the feedback we have received. With these changes, we believe your source to contract activities will be much simpler, faster and easier than ever.

Stay tuned for our additional upcoming blog posts and follow me to stay informed on upcoming feature releases across SAP Ariba. Once, these items are officially released on August 14th, the feature reference IDs (i.e. SC-22524) can help to find more detailed information on http://help.sap.com.

Thank you for being a part of the SAP Ariba community and we look forward to continuing our journey of innovation together!

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • What‚Äôs New

entry.title: Custom Situation Handling Trigger Accumulation Issue SAP S/4HANA 2023
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Currently, I am facing an issue with trigger accumulation while configuring a custom situation in the Manage Situation Types - Extended App. 
The goal is to accumulate posting block errors when posting billing documents to accounting, based on the Message Class, Message Number, and Company Code. The situation is configured as a batch based trigger. For instance, I would like to accumulate the posting block error for the error message F5201(posting period closed). The solution proposal will have a Mass Change Billing Date icon to update the billing document date for the trigger records. 

I created two CDS views which both select from the consumption view C_BillingDocument_F0797.

  1. The first CDS view is the anchor object structure. This view selects the Message Class, Message Number, and Company Code from C_BillingDocument_F0797. These three fields are used as the primary key for the view and anchor object, The view is grouped by these fields in the view to create a single unique record per primary key. The data is displayed as expected within the ADT data previewer. 
  2. The second CDS view is the trigger object structure. This view selects several fields from C_BillingDocument_F0797. The primary key  for the view and trigger object is a combination of Message Class, Message Number, Company Code, and Billing Document. With the hopes of accumulating based on the Billing Document for each situation instance created by the anchor object. Again, the data is displayed as expected within the ADT data previewer. 

I have configured the situation in various ways through the development. I have configured a single situation object with both structures and two situation objects (one for each anchor and trigger). However, when I trigger the batch based trigger for testing I am only seeing/receiving one trigger record per situation instance key. The trigger accumulation is enabled and the expectation would be to see several triggers per situation instance. 

I have followed various blog posts and SAP Help documents with no luck. 

Any insight is appreciated.

Thanks,
Jared

entry.title: Implications on not upgrading to SAPGUI 8.00
entry.content:
Hi SAP, 

1. Currently we are still using SAPGUI 770 patch level 3.  We are reviewing SAPGUI 8.0 with latest patch as the next replacement. 

However, we still have BW on prem servers and this is still using BEX, and this is only compatible to 32 bit office. 

 While reading more about SAPGUI, SAP note DIGITS mentioned that its safe to use 64 bit instead. Does SAPGUI 8.00 has compatible BEX for 64 bit as well? 

2. Also, what are the other effects if we have yet to upgrade to SAPGUI 8.0 aside from having new features, display and themes etc? 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Implications on not upgrading to SAPGUI 8.00
entry.content:
Hello customer,

Thank you for reaching out to us. 

Regarding your questions:

1.  The SAP GUI 8.00 indeed only supports  BEX 32-bit version. However, it is compatible with SAP GUI 8.00 64 bit version:

SAP Note 3218166 - SAP GUI for Windows: Functional differences of the 64bit version compared to the 32bit version:

  • SAP Business Explorer

    This component will not be supplied as a 64bit version. However, the 32bit version can be combined with a 64bit version of SAP GUI for Windows as long as a 32bit version of Microsoft Office is used. See also SAP Note 3213997. The 64bit installation of SAP GUI for Windows does not contain the 32bit component, you need to get this from a 32bit installation media or from another location. For more information please refer to support component BW-SYS-GUI.

SAP Note 3213997 - BI 7.x tools in 800- General Information & Limitations

2.Considering the support for SAP GUI for Windows 7.70 ended on 9th of April 2024 as per SAP Note 147519.  As of this date, release 7.70 will neither receive functional nor security corrections. Therefore, SAP strongly recommend an upgrade to SAP GUI for Windows 8.00, the only supported version which receives corrections and new features. In addition, SAP GUI 770 Patch level 03 is a very old one (the latest one is PL16, see SAP Note 1053737 - "Expected release dates for SAP GUI for Windows").

Also check SAP Note 3218166 :   

  • No support for 32bit versions of automation components

    The installation of a 64bit version of SAP GUI contains the automation components from SAP Note 2724656 (Logon Control, Table Control, Function Control and BAPI Control) only as 64bit versions. You cannot call these 64bit objects from 32bit processes like Microsoft Excel. If you need to use these components from 32bit processes, you need to keep using the 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows. This is one of the reasons why we generally recommend to take into account the features / bitness of other programs integrating with SAP GUI when deciding for a 64bit or 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows.

 

As per above mentioned information and BEX limitations/availability for SAP GUI 8.00 64 bit, we recommend you to upgrade it to SAP GUI 8.00 32-bit (latest patch level 13).

 

Thank you.

SAP Support.

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP Signavio Process Manager API
entry.content:
I‚Äôve worked with the SAP Signavio Process Manager API before, just enough to know how powerful it is and how confusing it can feel when you're getting started.

So when I was asked to put together a guide, I saw it as an opportunity to write the post I wish I‚Äôd had when I first started exploring the API. One that doesn‚Äôt just list the endpoints, but explains what to set up, how to authenticate and where to find examples that actually work.

If you're planning to build something with the API or just want to stop clicking through the UI 50 times a day, this guide is for you.

 

What you‚Äôll find in this guide:

  1. Understand When to Use SAP Signavio Process Manager API
  2. How Do I Access the API?
  3. Authentication: Logging In, the API Way
  4. Understand What Endpoints Are Available
  5. Dig Into Specific Requests and Responses
  6. What Happens When Things Go Wrong?
  7. Don‚Äôt Forget About Rate Limits
  8. Join the Developer Community

 

Understand When to Use SAP Signavio Process Manager API

The API is designed for users who want to automate tasks, build integrations, or programmatically interact with SAP Signavio Process Manager artifacts like folders, models, and dictionary entries.

Typical use cases include:

  • Creating and updating process diagrams at scale
  • Syncing dictionary items across systems
  • Building custom governance or quality-check pipelines
  • Extracting and analyzing model metadata for reporting

If you're manually clicking through the UI to perform repetitive actions, the API is probably a better fit.

 

First Things First: How Do I Access the API?

Before you can start sending requests to the SAP Signavio Process Manager API, you‚Äôll need the right kind of access. And no, not just ‚Äúa user account.‚Äù

You‚Äôll need:

  • A technical user (Step 1)
  • The API Edition license (Step 2)
  • A proper license assignment in your workspace (Step 3)

Here‚Äôs what that actually means in practice.

 

Step 1: Create a technical user (with a reachable email)

If you‚Äôre integrating with the API, it‚Äôs best to use a dedicated technical user account, not your personal Signavio login and not someone else‚Äôs either. The technical user should only have one thing: an API Edition license.

That‚Äôs important for two reasons:

  1. It enables headless authentication (no SSO required), which is essential for automation.
  2. It doesn‚Äôt consume a paid seat. Regular user licenses are charged, even if you‚Äôre just using them for API access.
 
üí° Best practice: Set up one technical user per integration scenario. And use a reachable, role-based email like signavio-integration@yourcompany.com. You‚Äôll need to access this mailbox for password resets and authentication.

For more information, view Setting up Technical Users.

 

Step 2: Get the API Edition license

Already have the API Edition license? Great - skip ahead to Step 3.

Don‚Äôt have it yet? No problem. In that case, you‚Äôll need to request one.

Go to SAP for Me and create a support case. Include your Tenant ID in the request. SAP Support will then add the license to your workspace, free of charge. For more information, view Reporting an Issue in the SAP Signavio Support Guide.

 

‚ö†Ô∏è Note: The license is provided at no additional cost. But don‚Äôt skip this step. Using a regular license for API access will eat up a paid seat and might result in unintended costs.

For more information, view Getting the License.

 

Step 3: Assign the API Edition license in your workspace

Assigning the API Edition license to technical users works like assigning any other license to a regular user. For more information, view User Accounts.

Once the user is set up, assign only the API Edition license. Don‚Äôt add any other license types. Then, make sure the user has the necessary permissions, like reading and writing. These permissions are granted via access rights. Find out more in Manage Access Rights.

You‚Äôre now ready to move past setup mode and into action. Let‚Äôs get you authenticated.

 

Authentication: Logging In, the API Way

Once your technical user is set up, you're ready to authenticate. At first, the flow might look a bit unusual if you haven‚Äôt worked with token-based authentication before, but it's easy to follow once you‚Äôve seen it in action.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

 

Step 1: Fetch JWT token

Send a POST request to https://{{host}}/auth/v1/token with your credentials.
You can find the correct host in the SAP Help documentation.

In the request body, provide:

  • The technical user‚Äôs email address
  • Their password
  • And your tenant ID (Find the Workspace ID)

You‚Äôll receive two things:

  1. JWT token (in the response body)
  2. JSESSIONID cookie (in the response header)

 

Step 2: Copy JWT token and cookie

Copy JWT token from the response body and JSESSIONID cookie from the response header.

 

Step 3: Call Resource API endpoint and include both JWT token and cookie in your requests

Call a Resource API endpoint (e.g. GET https://{{host}}/spm/v1/search) and:

  • Add x-signavio-id: <JWT token> to your headers
  • Set the cookie JSESSIONID=<sessionId>

You‚Äôll receive an API response:

The token stays valid for 8 hours. After that, you simply repeat the same request to get a fresh one. You can find more details in SAP Help.

 

Understand What Endpoints Are Available

‚Ä¶ and What to Do if One Is Missing

The SAP Signavio Process Manager API is structured around resource types, like dictionary entries, folders and diagrams. Each type has its own group of endpoints, all under the /spm/v1 base path.

You can use these endpoints to interact with key objects in SAP Signavio Process Manager. Whether you want to fetch all directories, create a new diagram, or update a dictionary entry, that all happens through this API.

That said, what you're seeing here isn‚Äôt the full picture. To explore the complete set of available endpoints, I recommend checking out these official resources:

  1. SAP Business Accelerator Hub - REST API
    A technical API reference in OpenAPI format - an industry standard you can interact with and download.
  2. SAP Help Portal
    Under ‚ÄúResource APIs‚Äù, you‚Äôll find request and response formats, common error codes and practical examples like retrieving models or navigating folders.
  3. GitHub - Postman Collection
    If you're hands-on and want to test things out, the Postman collection is a great place to start.
 
But What If Something‚Äôs Missing?

If you find yourself thinking, ‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt I do X?‚Äù, there‚Äôs a place to do something about it.

The SAP Customer Influence Portal is where customers and partners can submit API feature requests. You can also browse ideas from others, vote on them and follow their status. This helps the product team understand what‚Äôs most needed and why.

 

üí° Tip: If you hit a limitation, it‚Äôs always worth checking whether someone else already raised it. Adding your vote or use case can go a long way in getting it prioritized.

 

Dig Into Specific Requests and Responses

Example: Search API

Once you‚Äôve set up authentication (view earlier chapter), you‚Äôre ready to make real API calls. One useful example is searching across models, folders, and dictionary items in your workspace.

Let‚Äôs walk through the Search API. You can find more details in both SAP Help and the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

In this example, we want to search for the following SAP Signavio process model via the API:

The search endpoint is a simple GET request to:

üëâ https://{{host}}/spm/v1/search

You can find the correct host in the SAP Help documentation.

You can add parameters like q=yourQuery, limit=10, or types=MODEL to filter the results.

Here‚Äôs what that looks like in Postman:

The response is a JSON array of matching resources, each including metadata such as name, type, author and revision.

 

What Happens When Things Go Wrong?

Sooner or later, your request might fail. But the good news is: SAP Signavio gives you the tools to troubleshoot.

SAP provides detailed guidance on how to interpret error responses, common issues, and how to fix them. You‚Äôll find the most relevant information in two places:

 

1) SAP Business Accelerator Hub

The Business Hub lists expected responses for each endpoint, including all relevant HTTP error codes:

1. Go to the SAP Signavio Process Manager API in the Business Accelerator Hub.

2. Under ‚ÄúREST API‚Äù, select a section, such as Dictionary:

 

3. Navigate to ‚ÄúAPI Reference‚Äù and select an endpoint, such as POST /glossary:

4. Click to expand and scroll down to the Responses section:

2) SAP Help

You‚Äôll find a concise overview of common error codes and what they mean in the Troubleshooting section of the SAP Help documentation.

 

Still stuck?
Open a support ticket under component BPI-SIG-CA-API in SAP for Me. Don‚Äôt forget to include your workspace ID / tenant ID, request body and response log to speed up the investigation.

 

Don‚Äôt Forget About Rate Limits

Usage of SAP Signavio Process Manager APIs is monitored to ensure that our services are available fairly and reliably.

To prevent overload and ensure consistent performance, the API enforces usage limits. These rate limits define how many requests your application can send within a given time window.

You can find the exact thresholds and guidance in the official SAP Help documentation.

 

Join the Developer Community

Have a question? Built something cool? Share it!

The SAP Signavio developer community is a growing space where users share what they‚Äôve built, ask questions and exchange best practices. Whether you're stuck on a request, looking for inspiration, or want to showcase your latest integration, this is the place to be.

üß† Make sure to check out our Q&A and blog posts for more ideas and insights.

 

Thanks for reading! üéâ

I hope this guide gave you a solid foundation to start building and maybe even sparked some ideas along the way.

entry.title: Allocations distribution logic in SAC Planning Data Action
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
I'm working on a planning process in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) that distributes costs based on the number of units per cost center (CECO).

Here‚Äôs the logic I‚Äôve implemented:

  • I have a driver table where I input the distribution percentage by channel (e.g., Retail, Wholesale, E-commerce).

 

  • That percentage is then distributed proportionally based on the number of units per CECO.

The issue I‚Äôm facing is that if a CECO has no units reported, its portion of the percentage should be redistributed among the remaining CECOs that do have units.

Has anyone implemented a similar logic in a Data Action or Advanced Script in SAC Planning?
Thanks in advance!

entry.title: ODBC driver for ABAP examples on GitHub
entry.content:
Are you searching for practical examples of using the ODBC driver for ABAP in popular programming languages? Look no further‚Äîour GitHub repository has got you covered: ODBC Driver for ABAP Examples.

Currently, the repository features examples for the following languages:

  • C++
  • NodeJS
  • PowerShell
  • Python
  • Rust

These examples utilize a consistent set of ABAP objects, which are described in the repository. The example objects are also shipped with ABAP systems as part of the package SABP_DBC2ABAP_TEST.
We also provide a configuration template for unixodbc, our preferred driver manager for unix platforms.

Our examples not only demonstrate the capabilities of the ODBC driver for ABAP but also guide you on integrating it with the ODBC libraries specific to each language. Additionally, we aim to point out important limitations for each language.

We recognize the value of community contributions, and your input is invaluable. If there's a particular language or feature you think should be included, don‚Äôt hesitate to let us know. You can create an issue on GitHub, or, even better, contribute by submitting a pull request with your own example.

entry.title: Common set-up issues of Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
This Blog continues my previous setup blog post - Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - A Comprehensive Setup Guide. 

Note: The below are general findings. For detailed analysis of issues, we recommend checking the SAP Help Portal or working with SAP Incidents. 

You can find the list of the most common issues here:

  1. Joule is not answering as expected, but only giving instructions on how to access information
  2. Joule is not greeting you with your name or showing a blank screen
  3. Joule responds with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm having trouble connecting.‚Äù

 

1.      Joule is not answering as expected, but only giving instructions on how to access information

Reason: This is often a sign that the actual logged-on user has insufficient roles assigned or that the assigned roles are not known to Joule.

 

Fix: Joule requires access to the actual backend system and needs to know about assigned S/4HANA user roles to pre-select appropriate capabilities.

Some Joule capabilities are linked to Semantic Objects and Actions, so only users with access to those Semantic Objects will also be able to access them via Joule. Typically, when the respective Fiori app is accessible to the user, this will also grant access via Joule. However, it‚Äôs important that user/role assignments are replicated to Workzone and, therefore, known to Joule.

Figure 1: The picture on the left shows the expected response, while the right picture shows that Joule does a fallback citing user assistance resources.

When Joule does not find the respective role assigned to a user, it will resort to informational capabilities, such as citing out-of-help documentation.

a. Check if there is a capability available in the catalog that allows Joule to actually access data from a backend, see the help documentation

b. Find the required Semantic Objects and Actions for each Joule Capability in the SAP Note 3523238 attached spreadsheet

c. Check if your SAP S/4HANA Cloud version supports that capability (see column F)

Note: In case of a release upgrade of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system, you must trigger an update of Joule‚Äôs capability catalog. To do so in your SAP BTP Global Account, go to Formations, find the relevant Joule formation, and Exclude and afterwards Include your S/4HANA Private Cloud system.

d. Check if the respective Fiori app is included within your exposed CDM content.

In transaction /UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE go to ‚ÄúPreview Content‚Äù, ensure that the respective user role has the Fiori App ID linked

Fiori apps, their App IDs, and Semantic Objects and Actions can be found in the Fiori Apps Library.

 

Transactions /n/ui2/flia or /n/UI2/FLPCM_CUST allows to find Roles for a specific Semantic Object:

e. Go to your SAP Build Work Zone Admin -> Channel Manager and check if the CDM content was properly read from S/4HANA. Note the ‚ÄúReport‚Äù only shows newly created artifacts.

In case of errors, click ‚Äúedit‚Äù to find the name of the ‚ÄúDesign Time‚Äù destination. Within your BTP Cockpit check you can do a Connection test of the destination:

 

Further help:

https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/troubleshooting-e69b6f5d31a542c6a5f87c8b45c1d427

Besides also it is also recommended to schedule a job to regularly update content: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/a7b390faab1140c087b8926571e942b7/a6e718dcfe4f47e5adc71078bb35ec74.html?version=202110.000

 

f.  Go to your SAP Build Work Zone Admin -> Settings -> SAP Identity Provisioning and check if your user has the necessary roles assigned. These can also be customer-specific roles; it is important that the standard Fiori applications with their Semantic Objects (see column D above) are included within those roles.

PS: SAP Build Work Zone also offers an API for advanced scenarios; you can find details here.

If no roles are listed, check the provisioning jobs in Cloud Identity services ‚Äì Identity Provisioning service (IPS) for errors or filter conditions.

 

g. Check if the necessary OData API was activated in your system 

 

2. Joule is not greeting you with your name or showing a blank screen

Issue: When Joule is not greeting you with your name, it is an indication that the wrong identity is used and not mapped to the identity in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Fix: Joule requires a global user identity within all connected systems to act on behalf of the business user. Therefore, Joule uses an identity stored locally within SAP Cloud Identity services (Identity Directory). It is important that user attributes (first name, last name, email, global user ID) are properly mapped from potential third-party identity providers to a local identity in SAP Cloud Identity services, and the same are forwarded to Joule during authentication.

 

  • Ensure that your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system is configured to use the very same SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant for authentication as your Joule instance.
  • Ensure that the top-level domain (e.g., cloud.sap or ondemand.com) is set-up consistent within your landscape.

In SAP S/4HANA, check transaction SAML2 -> Trusted Providers

 

In BTP Cockpit -> your Joule subaccount -> Trust Configuration -> check the ‚ÄúDomain‚Äù selection:

  • Ensure that the global user id is distributed across your complete landscape

In transaction SU01 -> open the respective business users -> click ‚ÄúGoto‚Äù -> click ‚ÄúExternal user id (UID)‚Äù and validate that the same ID is maintained as within SAP Cloud Identity Services, Identity Directory (‚ÄúGlobal User ID‚Äù).

See also: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity/system-integration-guide/global-user-id-in-integration-scenarios?locale=en-US

 

3. Joule responds with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm having trouble connecting.‚Äù

Issue: When Joule responds, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm having trouble connecting. Please make sure you are online and can access your SAP system,‚Äù this indicates that Joule tried to access the backend but was not able to access it.

Fix: Often, the principal propagation between Joule, BTP Destination, SAP Cloud Connector, WebDispatcher, ICM, and the API within the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition system is broken.

You can trace Joule‚Äôs interactions for a specific user by starting an HTTP Payload trace in transaction /n/IWDFND/TRACES

 

A very good troubleshooting guide can be found here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/appservices/3361376259.html

Other helpful resources:

https://github.com/SAP-archive/cloud-platform-connectivity-principal-propagation/blob/master/exercises/B2/README.md

https://help.sap.com/doc/si/1.0/en-US/attachments/3362959224/WebDispatcherSSLCertificateForwarding_V3.pdf

 

Cheers, 

Happy Learning. 

Credits and Co-Written with RIG Team - @mathias Rup
